jqoBiKUB.title: Climate Characteristic Analysis of Binzhou City,Lubei Region
jqoBiKUB.abstract: The trend of drought in the city of Binzhou(Lubei region) was analyzed,with the data of precipitation,air temperature and humidity during 1971 to 2000.It was found that the precipitation was decreasing by 26 mm every 10 years,while the temperature was increasing by 0.3 ℃ per decade.The temperature in the summer and autumn was increasing.And the temperature in 1990's was higher over 0.5 ℃ than that in 1970's,while the temperature in the winter was up to 1.4 ℃.This was inaccord with the global warm-up.It was also found that in the recent 30 years the general climate was in the trend of decreasing precipitation and increasing temperature,and the local water-warm balance was in a brand new situation.The annual humidity was in a trend of decline,and the climate was in a situation of drought.Humidity index was in decreasing by 0.057 every 10 years.The main reason was that precipitation was decreasing while the temperature was increasing every year.Therefore,transpiration was increasing by 26.88 mm every 10 years.So the situation of drought in Binzhou was directly related to decadal changes of subtropics high atmospheric pressure index,subtropics high atmospheric acreage and intensity and decadal changes of pole-whorl average latitude and average longitude.

kKhGFJK0.title: Layered Li-Mn oxides with the O2 structure: Preparation of Li 2/3[Mn1-xMx]O2 (M=Li, Cr, Mg, Al) by ion exchange
kKhGFJK0.abstract: Layered sodium manganese bronzes, Na2/3[Mn1-xM x]O2 (M=Li, Cr, Mg, Al) with the P2 structure have been investigated. In the case of M=Li, the location of the dopant was identified on the basis of ion-exchange properties and chemical analysis. With the increase doped Cr content, the P2-structure Na2/3[Mn1-xCr x]O2 gradually underwent a transformation to orthorhombic Na4[Mn9-yCry]O18. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was used to measure the oxidation state and the composition near the surface. The compositions near the surface and in the bulk were found to vary with the identity of the doped element. The O2-structure lithium manganese oxides were prepared from Na-bronzes by ion exchange, but the crystallinity decreased after the ion exchange as a result of stacking faults. © 2003 Elsevier B.V. zcPYO1aO.title: Preparation and crystal structure of Liy[Mn1-xM x]O2 (M = Cr, Mg) with the layered O2 structure
zcPYO1aO.abstract: Precursors of the P2 type Na2/3[Mn1-xM x]O2 (M = Cr, Mg) were prepared by solid state reaction methods and Liy[Mn1-xMx]O2 materials were obtained by ion-exchange. XRD patterns indicate that Li y[Mn1-xMx]-O2 has the layered O2 structure with the hexagonal space group P3ml. It is shown by XRD that the structure of the Cr-doped precursors is influenced by the dopant content. When 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.05, Na2/3[Mn1-xCrx]O2 materials with the P2 structure were obtained. When x > 0.05, the structure was gradually changed from P2 structure to orthorhombic Na4Mn 9O18. X-ray photoelectron spectra indicate that surface and bulk compositions of Liy[Mn0.95Cr0.05] O2 are different. The oxidation states of manganese and chromium in the near-surface region are largely tetravalent and the Cr/Mn ratio in the near-surface region is higher than that in the bulk. The presence of Mn 4+ and Cr-rich surface layers leads to an improvement in the stability of the material. In the case of the Mg-doped compounds, however, layered O2-type structure Liy[Mn1-xMgx]O 2 materials can be obtained in the range of 0 ≤ x ≤ 0.15. The layered structure becomes more distinct as the content of Mg increases. The Mg/Mn ratio in the near-surface region is consistent with that in the bulk, indicating the formation of stoichiometric Mg-Mn mixed oxides.

rJlhgYqu.title: Characterization of structure and electrochemical properties of lithium manganese oxides for lithium secondary batteries hydrothermally synthesized from δ-KxMnO2
rJlhgYqu.abstract: Lithium manganese oxides have attracted much attention as cathode materials for lithium secondary batteries in view of their high capacity and low toxicity. In this study, layered manganese oxide (δ-K x MnO 2 ) has been synthesized by thermal decomposition of KMnO 4 , and four lithium manganese oxide phases have been synthesized for the first time by mild hydrothermal reactions of this material with different lithium compounds. The lithium manganese oxides were characterized by powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), inductively coupled plasma emission (ICPE) spectroscopy, and chemical redox titration. The four materials obtained are rock salt structure Li 2 MnO 3 , hollandite (BaMn 8 O 16 ) structure α-MnO 2 , spinel structure LiMn 2 O 4 , and birnessite structure Li x MnO 2 . Their electrochemical properties used as cathode material for secondary lithium batteries have been investigated. Of the four lithium manganese oxides, birnessite structure Li x MnO 2 demonstrated the most stable cycling behavior with high Coulombic efficiency. Its reversible capacity reaches 155 mAh g −1 , indicating that it is a viable cathode material for lithium secondary batteries. Keywords Lithium manganese oxides Hydrothermal synthesis δ-K x MnO 2 Lithium secondary batteries Cathode materials

UtEz8dy4.title: Uptake of chloride ion from aqueous solution by calcined layered double hydroxides: equilibrium and kinetic studies.
UtEz8dy4.abstract: Layered double hydroxides (LDH) calcined within a certain temperature range (denoted as CLDH) have been shown to recover their original layered structure in the presence of appropriate anions. In the light of this so-called "memory effect", uptake of chloride ion from aqueous solution by calcined MgAl-CO3 LDH was investigated in batch mode. The equilibrium isotherm showed that the uptake of chloride ion by CLDH was consistent with the Langmuir and Freundlich equations and that the Langmuir model gave a better fit to the experimental data than the Freundlich model. The maximum uptake capacity of CLDH for chloride ion was 149.5 mg/g, close to the stoichiometric uptake (168 mg/g). The influence of varying pH of solution, initial chloride concentration, adsorbent quantity, and temperature on the kinetics of chloride removal has also been explored. Four kinetic models were used to fit the experimental data, and it was found that the pseudo-second-order kinetics model could be used to describe the uptake process satisfactorily. The calculated value of Ea was found to be 56.8 kJ/mol, which suggests that the process of uptake of chloride ion is controlled by the rate of reaction of chloride ion with the CLDH rather than diffusion. A mechanism for removal of chloride ion has been confirmed by X-ray diffraction, FT-IR spectroscopy and TG-MS measurements.

guqUuhIn.title: Synthesis of LiMnO2 by Solid State Reaction in Air and the Influence of Ion Exchange Conditions on Its Structure
guqUuhIn.abstract: Layered sodium manganese bronze NaMnO2 with a monoclinic structure has been synthesized in air. Its structure is similar to the bronze synthesized in argon. The precursor was used to prepare layered LiMnO2 by ion exchange of Na+ by Li+ under different ion exchange conditions: in a LiCl/LiNO3 eutectic at 300 °C, in n-hexanol at 145 °C, in water at 105 °C, and in ethanol at 95 °C. X-ray diffraction indicates that the precursor and ion exchange products have a layered structure with the monoclinic space group C2/m. Both XRD and ICP analysis demonstrate that temperature influences the rate of the ion exchange reaction and the crystal structure of LiMnO2 in each case. The higher the temperature, the faster the reaction, and the more severe the distortion of the products. SEM micrographs show that LiMnO2 possesses a needle-like morphology.

cQNYumz8.title: Controllable preparation of Nano-MgO and investigation of its bactericidal properties.
cQNYumz8.abstract: Samples of nano-MgO with varying particle sizes were prepared by four different methods using Mg(NO3)2.6H2O, Na2CO3, urea and ammonia as raw materials and characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), low temperature N2 adsorption-desorption measurements and FT-IR spectroscopy. Bactericidal experiments with Bacillus subtilis var. niger and Staphylococcus aureus were carried out using as-synthesized nano-MgO samples and the bactericidal mechanism was also investigated. The results showed that the bactericidal efficacy of nano-MgO increases with decreasing particle size. The bactericidal efficacy of the samples was compared with that of TiO2, a common photoactive bactericidal material. The nano-MgO has better bactericidal activity, both when used directly and as an additive in an interior wall paint. Furthermore, nano-MgO is active even in the absence of irradiation.

Vg6vTdzQ.title: In situ FT-IR, in situ HT-XRD and TPDE study of thermal decomposition of sulfated β-cyclodextrin intercalated in layered double hydroxides
Vg6vTdzQ.abstract: The thermal decomposition behavior of an intercalate derived from magnesium–aluminum layered double hydroxide (Mg/Al LDH) and hexa-sulfated β-cyclodextrin [NaSO 3 -β-CD(6)] has been studied by in situ Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy, in situ high temperature X-ray diffraction (HT-XRD), temperature-programmed decomposition (TPDE), thermogravimetry (TG), and differential thermal analysis (DTA). In situ FT-IR shows that the decomposition of glucose groups of β-CD is complete at 230, 170 and 270 °C in NaSO 3 -β-CD(6), HSO 3 -β-CD(6) and SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH, respectively, indicating that intercalation of the SO 3 -β-CD(6) anion into an LDH host can increase its thermal stability. In the hybrid compound SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH the - SO 3 - groups are gradually converted to SO 4 2 - which are grafted to the LDH layers. In situ XRD shows that there are two decreases in d 0 0 3 basal spacing of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH observed in the temperature range 20–150 °C and 200–350 °C. The first corresponds to the destruction of the interlayer hydrogen bonding area and the second is attributed to the decomposition of SO 3 -β-CD(6) and dehydroxylation of the LDH layers. TPDE combined with GC-MS is used for the first time to study the thermal decomposition of LDHs, and the results are in accordance with those from in situ FT-IR, in situ XRD and TG-DTA. Keywords Sulfated β-cyclodextrin Layered double hydroxide Intercalation Thermal decomposition In situ FT-IR In situ HT-XRD TPDE 1 Introduction Layered double hydroxides (LDHs) are a class of anionic clays which can be represented by the general formula [ M 1 - x II M x III ( OH ) 2 ] x + (A n − ) x / n · m H 2 O [1] , where M II , M III are di- and tri-valent metal cations respectively. LDHs have positively charged layers and a wide variety of charge-balancing anionic species have been intercalated into the gallery region. As a result, LDHs are now well established as excellent anion-exchange materials and their extensive intercalation chemistry has widespread applications in areas such as heterogeneous catalysis [2,3] , separation science [4,5] . Cyclodextrins are cyclic oligosaccharides of d -glucopyranose that possess a unique structure containing a non-polar doughnut-shaped ring which can accommodate different kinds of compounds in the cavity [6–9] . Cyclodextrins and their derivatives are excellent “host” components for the microencapsulation of a wide variety of organic, as well as inorganic guest molecules, forming host-guest inclusion complexes in aqueous solution [6] . In 1998, Zhao and Vance reported the intercalation of carboxymethyl-β-cyclodextrin in LDHs as well as its sorption affinity for organic compounds [10,11] . Sulfated cyclodextrins have been widely used for enantiomeric separation, either by liquid chromatography using columns containing the materials bound to a solid support [12,13] or by capillary electrophoresis [14,15] . The intercalation of sulfated cyclodextrins in the confined interlayer region of LDHs should give rise to a new type of stationary phase for liquid chromatography with high chiral selectivity and low degree of leaching. In our previous paper [16] , a hexa sulfated β-cyclodextrin has been intercalated into a magnesium–aluminum LDH, and its structure and chemical composition have been studied. Ex situ X-ray diffraction (XRD) and thermal analysis have been generally used to investigate the decomposition process of LDHs [17–19] . Ex situ studies have the disadvantage that mixed oxides derived from LDHs may rehydrate and reconstruct to give the original structure at ambient temperature in air. In situ infrared spectroscopy has been used to provide structural information about the dehydroxylation and decarbonation process in LDHs [20–23] , and Pérez-Ramírez et al. have studied the thermal decomposition of Co-Al and Ni-Al hydrotalcites by in situ Fourier transform infrared and laser Raman spectroscopies [24] . Temperature-programmed decomposition (TPDE) [25] has been generally used for the study of catalysts and the decomposition of LDHs has not been studied using this method. In the present work, the thermal decomposition process of sulfated β-cyclodextrin intercalated LDH has been investigated by in situ FT-IR, in situ HT-XRD, TPDE and TG-DTA. To the best of our knowledge, combined application of in situ techniques to investigate the decomposition of organic molecule-intercalated LDHs has not been reported elsewhere. Therefore, this work provides information about the thermal decomposition of the cyclodextrin-LDH hybrid. An understanding of the thermal stability is important in view of its potential application on a novel stationary phase for liquid chromatography. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Reagents All reagents including Mg(NO 3 ) 2 · 6H 2 O, Al(NO 3 ) 3 · 9H 2 O, NaOH, NaNO 3 , Na 2 CO 3 , CaCO 3 , ethanol, ether, acetone, sulfuric acid and β-cyclodextrin were of analytical grade. β-cyclodextrin was purchased from Aldrich, and the others from Beijing Chemical Plant Limited. 2.2 Synthesis of hexa-sulfated β-cyclodextrin and SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH The sodium salt of hexa-sulfated β-cyclodextrin, NaSO 3 -β-CD(6), was synthesized according to the procedure described in the literature [26] . HSO 3 -β-CD(6), the acid form corresponding to protonated NaSO 3 -β-CD(6), was obtained by recrystallization after adjusting the pH of the NaSO 3 -β-CD(6) solution. The precursor [Mg 4 Al 2 (OH) 12 ](NO 3 ) 2 · 4H 2 O (represented as Mg/Al-NO 3 LDH) was synthesized by a procedure similar to that described previously [1] . SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH was synthesized according to the procedure described in our previous paper [16] . 2.3 Characterization In situ HT-XRD measurements were performed on a Rigaku D/max 2500VB2+/PC diffractometer in vacuum, using CuKα radiation ( λ = 0.154 nm) at 40 kV, 30 mA. The samples as unoriented powders were scanned in steps of 0.02° in the 2 θ range 2°–70° using a count time of 4 s per step. In situ FT-IR spectra were recorded using a Nicolet 60sxb spectrometer in the range 4000 to 400 cm −1 with 2 cm −1 resolution. The spectra were obtained every 10° with a heating rate of 5 °C/min under the protection of a nitrogen atmosphere. The standard KBr disk method (1 mg of sample in 100 mg of KBr) was used. TPDE of the samples was carried out using an MRCS-2000 instrument under flowing helium in the temperature range 30–500 °C with heating rate of 2 °C/min. The decomposition products were analyzed by GC-MS on a Shimadzu GCMS-QP2010 instrument. Helium was used as carrier gas at flow rate of 0.92 ml/min. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH The X-ray diffraction patterns of the precursor Mg/Al-NO 3 LDH and the NaSO 3 -β-CD(6) intercalated LDH are shown in Fig. 1 . In each case, the reflections can be indexed to a hexagonal lattice with R -3m rhombohedral symmetry, commonly used for the description of the LDH structures. As shown in Fig. 1 a, the strongest peak of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH is the (0 0 6) reflection, while the (0 0 3) reflection has the strongest peak intensity in the diffraction pattern of the LDH precursor. This is possibly related to the presence of a carbonate-containing LDH impurity phase which is often observed even when intercalation reactions are carried out under nitrogen. The peak around 11° may be a superposition of the (0 0 3) reflection of the LDH-carbonate and the (0 0 6) reflection of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH, accounting for its enhanced intensity. The peak around 23° can be assigned to the (0 0 6) reflection of LDH-carbonate. This will be further discussed in the section of in situ HT-XRD below. Elemental analysis data show that the chemical composition of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH is Mg 0.70 Al 0.34 (OH) 2 (SO 3 CD(6)) 0.05 (CO 3 ) 0.05 (NO 3 ) 0.01 · 0.04H 2 O. It can be seen that not all of the NO 3 - anions have been exchanged by SO 3 -β-CD(6), which has been observed by other authors in studies of intercalation of large anions in Mg/Al-NO 3 LDH precursors [27,28] . Some carbonate containing LDH coexists with the SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH, which is consistent with the XRD results. The total exclusion of carbonate from the interlayer space of LDHs is known to be difficult, which can be readily explained on the basis of the favorable lattice stabilization enthalpy associated with the small and highly charged CO 3 2 - anions [29] . 3.2 Thermal decomposition by in situ FT-IR Infrared spectra recorded during the decomposition of NaSO 3 -β-CD(6), HSO 3 -β-CD(6), SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH in the temperature range 24–450 °C are presented in Figs. 2–4 , respectively. NaSO 3 -β-CD(6) and HSO 3 -β-CD(6) were used as reference samples here. 3.2.1 Analysis of as-synthesized samples As shown in Fig. 2 , in the infrared spectrum at room temperature of the as-synthesized NaSO 3 -β-CD(6), a broad strong absorption band at 3427 cm −1 is observed, which can be attributed to OH combination stretching vibrations of hydroxyl groups and physically adsorbed water [30] . An absorption at 2923 cm −1 is due to the stretching vibration of CH 2 , and that at 1659 cm −1 is due to HOH bending of physically adsorbed water. Bands at 1159, 1027 and 943 cm −1 are assigned to absorption of C–O, C–O–C of glucose units and C–O–C of the rings respectively [31] , while those at 1267 and 1059 cm −1 are attributed to asymmetric stretching vibrations of SO 2 and S–O respectively [32] . Fig. 3 displays the infrared spectra of HSO 3 -β-CD(6), the acid form corresponding to protonated NaSO 3 -β-CD(6). Its spectrum at room temperature is in accordance with that of NaSO 3 -β-CD(6) except that the position of the absorption band attributed to SO 2 decreases from 1267 ( Fig. 5 a) to 1252 cm −1 ( Fig. 5 b). This is related to the formation of an O-H bond in HSO 3 -β-CD(6), bringing about the shift to low frequency of the asymmetric stretching vibration of SO 2 compared with that of NaSO 3 -β-CD(6). The infrared spectrum at room temperature of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH is shown in Fig. 4 . The very broad absorption band centered at 3467 cm −1 is assigned to the OH stretching vibration of hydroxyl groups, water molecules in the interlayer and physically adsorbed water [30] . The OH group of SO 3 -β-CD(6) and that of the LDH layers form a strong hydrogen bond resulting in a shift of the OH band to high frequency compared with NaSO 3 -β-CD(6) (3427 cm −1 ) and HSO 3 -β-CD(6) (3424 cm −1 ). The band at 1640 cm −1 is due to HOH bending of physically adsorbed water and bands at 1155, 1027 and 942 cm −1 correspond to absorption by C–O, C–O–C of glucose units and C–O–C of rings respectively. The lattice vibrations of metal cations Al 3+ and Mg 2+ can be seen at 826 and 668 cm −1 [33] . The bands at 1383 and 1385 cm −1 are due to the stretching vibrations of NO 3 - and CO 3 2 - [19,34] . The co-intercalation of these anions along with SO 3 -β-CD(6) is also shown by XRD and elemental analysis [16] . The bands at 1059 and 1254 cm −1 are attributed to the stretching vibrations of C–O–S and SO 2 respectively. Compared with NaSO 3 -β-CD(6), the stretching vibration of SO 2 in SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH moves 13 cm −1 to low frequency. This may indicate the different strengths of hydrogen bonding, which is weaker in the sodium salt precursor ( Fig. 5 a) and higher in the interlayer region of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH ( Fig. 5 c). 3.2.2 Thermal decomposition monitored by in situ FT-IR From Fig. 2 , it can be observed that the absorption bands at 1159, 1027, 943, 2923 and 3427 cm −1 attributed to the C–O, C–O–C of glucose units, C–O–C rings, CH 2 and OH groups respectively [31] , become weaker on increasing the temperature from 24 to 200 °C, and disappear at 230 °C. This indicates that the decomposition of NaSO 3 -β-CD(6) involves dehydroxylation and the breaking of C–O–C bands both within and between glucose units. The changes in the position of the band centered at 1267 cm −1 which is attributed to the asymmetric stretching of SO 2 [35] , are very interesting. When the temperature increases to 200 °C, the absorbance of SO 2 moves from 1267 to 1225 cm −1 , while it shifts in the reverse direction to 1253 cm −1 in the temperature range 200–270 °C. This variation is possibly related to the formation of hydrogen bonds between – SO 3 - and OH. At lower temperatures, – SO 3 - and OH cannot form hydrogen bonds or the hydrogen bonds formed are very weak due to the space restriction. However with increasing temperature, OH is released from the glucose moieties, and it is possible for – SO 3 - and free OH to form hydrogen bonds which reach a maximum at 200 °C. As a result, the band moves to low frequency, and the frequency reaches a minimum at 200 °C. With the continuous loss of the free OH groups between 200 and 270 °C, the wavenumber of the absorption band of SO 2 increases to 1253 cm −1 because of breaking of hydrogen bonds. At 270 °C, the band at 1253 cm −1 becomes very weak and a new band at 1103 cm −1 appears. When the temperature is above 300 °C, the band at 1254 cm −1 becomes insignificant, while strong bands at 1104 and 611 cm −1 appear. These changes confirm that SO 3 - groups are eventually converted to SO 4 2 - . As SO 4 2 - has a tetrahedral structure, only symmetric stretching (1105 cm −1 ) and out-of-plane deformation (611 cm −1 ) bands are IR-active [35] . Fig. 3 shows the in situ variable temperature FT-IR spectra of HSO 3 -β-CD(6). The bands at 3424 and 2927 cm −1 due to hydroxyl groups and CH 2 groups respectively become weaker with increasing temperature and disappear at 200 °C. Bands at 1157, 1024 and 940 cm −1 attributed to glucose units disappear at 170 °C, as compared with 230 °C for NaSO 3 -β-CD(6) ( Fig. 2 ). The characteristic absorption bands of SO 4 2 - at 1100 and 611 cm −1 are observed at 250 °C, indicating the transformation of – SO 3 - groups to SO 4 2 - . The decomposition temperature of HSO 3 -β-CD(6) is lower than that of NaSO 3 -β-CD(6), indicating lower thermal stability of the free acid compared with its salt. As shown in Fig. 4 , infrared spectra of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH recorded at higher temperatures follow a similar trend as that observed for the two reference samples. However, there are some differences between them. The absorption band at 3467 cm −1 becomes weaker with increasing temperature, and disappears at 450 °C, as a result of loss of water as well as hydroxyl groups of β-CD and the LDH layers. The decrease in intensities of the absorption bands arising from the glucose units and SO 2 groups is insignificant in the temperature range 24–200 °C, while there is a sharp decrease at 250 °C, and the bands completely disappear at 270 °C. From 24–200 °C, the intercalated SO 3 -β-CD(6) is located in a restricted interlayer region with water of crystallization occupying the free space. As a result, its rate of decomposition is rather slow, which is possibly a result of limitations imposed on the diffusion of the interlayer guests. When the temperature is above 200 °C, the loss of interlayer water is almost complete and dehydroxylation occurs. Therefore, there is more free interlayer space in the LDH, and the diffusion process is not the rate-determining step of the decomposition of intercalated SO 3 -β-CD(6). Consequently, decomposition occurs rapidly during the temperature range 200–250 °C, and is complete at 270 °C. The variation in the bands at 1383 and 1385 cm −1 attributed to interlayer NO 3 - and CO 3 2 - follows a similar pattern and the bands almost disappear at 250 °C, in accordance with the analysis of in situ XRD which will be further discussed below. Moreover, at 150 °C there is a new peak observed at 1107 cm −1 , which is assigned to the absorption of SO 4 2 - as previously discussed. It becomes stronger with increasing temperature, and shifts to 1104 cm −1 at 250 °C. However, a doublet at 1147 and 1109 cm −1 appears at 270 °C. The former band becomes stronger and the latter becomes weaker with the increase of temperature. Only a broad band centered at 1140 cm −1 is observed above 400 °C, which may be assigned to SO 4 2 - grafted to the LDH layers (as shown in Fig. 5 d). Constantino and Pinnavaia reported that grafting of sulfate to adjacent LDH layers occurs above 250 °C [36] , and the absorption band of grafted SO 4 2 - (1147 cm −1 ) was observed at 270 °C in our study, in agreement with their results. 3.3 Thermal decomposition monitored by in situ HT-XRD The in situ HT-XRD patterns of the intercalation product SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH in the temperature range 20–700 °C are shown in Fig. 6 . The variations in the d 0 0 3 basal spacing of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH and CO 3 2 - /LDH with temperature are shown in Fig. 7 a and b, respectively. At 20 °C, the strongest peak (see Fig. 6 ) of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH is the (0 0 6) reflection (2 θ 11°), which may be a superposition of the (0 0 3) reflection of CO 3 2 - /LDH and the (0 0 6) reflection of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH, accounting for its enhanced intensity. The peak around 23° (marked with ■) can be assigned to the (0 0 6) reflection of CO 3 2 - LDH. This will be discussed further below. When heated to 150 °C, the (0 0 3), (0 0 6) and (0 0 9) diffraction peaks of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH clearly move to higher angle 2 θ (as shown in Fig. 6 ) with the (0 0 3) basal spacing decreasing from 1.618 to 1.406 nm ( Fig. 7 a). The (0 0 6) peak of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH (marked with * in Fig. 6 ) and (0 0 3) peak of CO 3 2 - LDH (marked with # in Fig. 6 ), which overlap at room temperature, are separated at 100 °C. This change probably results from the destruction of the interlayer hydrogen bonding area [34] in SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH associated with the loss of gallery water. Taking into account the decrease in d 0 0 3 basal spacing between 20 and 150 °C, the height of the interlayer hydrogen bonding area is calculated to be 0.212 nm (1.618–1.406 nm), which is close to the literature value of 0.27 nm [37] . The value of d 0 0 3 basal spacing is almost constant in the temperature range 150–200 °C, while it decreases from 1.402 nm at 200 °C to 1.140 nm at 350 °C. The layered structure is lost at 400 °C (see Fig. 6 ). These changes result from the decomposition of SO 3 -β-CD(6) and dehydroxylation of LDH layers, and are in accordance with the in situ FT-IR analysis where it was shown that SO 3 -β-CD(6) is converted to grafted SO 4 2 - at 400 °C. For the interlayer impurity phase CO 3 2 - /LDH, its (0 0 3) diffraction peak (marked with # in Fig. 6 ) is clearly observed at 100 °C due to the shift in position of the (0 0 6) peak of the SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH phase, which was previously coincident with it. It can be seen from Fig. 7 b that the change in d 0 0 3 basal spacing of CO 3 2 - LDH is negligible in the range 20–200 °C, in contrast to that of the SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH phase. This is possibly related to the different hydrogen bonded network, existing in the two materials. However, both the (0 0 3) and (0 0 6) peaks of the CO 3 2 - phase disappear at 230 °C, indicating completely decarbonation which is consisted with the results from in situ FT-IR spectroscopy at 250 °C. 3.4 Thermal decomposition studied by TPDE TPDE can be used to study the kinetics of adsorbate desorption, decomposition, surface catalysed reactions of adsorbates and a reactive gas in the carrier gas stream as well as reaction between co-adsorbates [38] . This technique is commonly applied in surface science and catalysis to determine surface coverage of adsorbates and to determine adsorption energies [39] . However, it has not previously been used to study the decomposition of LDHs. In this study, TPDE together with GC-MS were used to determine the intermediates formed during thermal reaction of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH, and hence, the reaction pathway can be deduced. The TPDE profile ( Fig. 8 ) displays three decomposition peaks at 118, 166 and 378 °C. The first peak at 118 °C is due to the loss of physically absorbed water, as shown by the H 2 O detected by GC-MS. The second peak observed at 166 °C can be attributed to the loss of interlayer crystal water, as H 2 O was also detected by GC-MS. At the same time, some small organic fragments with molecular weight 32, 43 and 57 were detected by GC-MS at around 250 °C, which suggests that the interlayer SO 3 -β-CD(6) has begun to decompose. These organic fragments and water molecules coexist, so a broad peak between 166 and 300 °C was observed in the TPDE profile. In the temperature range 350–450 °C, organic fragments with molecular weight 32, 43, 57 and 71 were detected, suggesting that this process corresponds to further decomposition of the guests as well as the dehydroxylation of the host layers. 3.5 TG-DTA analysis The TG and DTA curves for the SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH intercalate are shown in Fig. 9 . The thermal decomposition of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH is characterized by four weight loss steps ( Fig. 9 a): the first (20–130 °C) is due to loss of both adsorbed water and interlayer water molecules which is confirmed by in situ XRD pattern at 100 °C ( Fig. 6 ); the second (130–250 °C) is a consequence of both the decomposition of the SO 3 -β-CD(6) and the elimination of interlayer water, which has a corresponding broad weak exothermic peak in the DTA curve ( Fig. 9 b), in accordance with the above analysis of the in situ FT-IR ( Fig. 4 ) and TPDE data; the third (250–540 °C) can be attributed to dehydroxylation and decomposition of SO 3 -β-CD(6). The fourth stage (620–670 °C) can be attributed to the combustion of SO 3 -β-CD(6), with a corresponding strong exothermic peak at 665 °C in the DTA curve ( Fig. 9 b). It should be noted that the fourth stage (combustion) was not observed by TPDE, since helium was used as the carrier gas. 4 Conclusions In situ FT-IR, in situ HT-XRD, TPDE and TG-DTA have been used to study physicochemical changes during the thermal decomposition of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH. As shown by infrared spectroscopy, the asymmetric stretching vibration of SO 2 is at 1267, 1252 and 1254 cm −1 in NaSO 3 -β-CD(6), HSO 3 -β-CD(6) and SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH, respectively. Hydrogen bonding in the last two compounds results in the red-shift of the absorption of SO 2 groups compared with NaSO 3 -β-CD(6). In situ infrared spectra at high temperature reveal significant differences between these compounds. The decomposition of glucose groups of β-CD is complete at 230, 170 and 270 °C in NaSO 3 -β-CD(6), HSO 3 -β-CD(6) and SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH, respectively, indicating that intercalation of the SO 3 -β-CD(6) anion into an LDH host can increase its thermal stability. The decomposition of glucose groups in the range 24–200 °C is much lower in the intercalate than in the sodium salt form, but its decomposition occurs rapidly between 200 and 250 °C, and is complete at 270 °C. This is possibly because interlayer diffusion is the rate-determining step in the former temperature region. It has been confirmed by in situ FT-IR spectroscopy that – SO 3 - is gradually converted to SO 4 2 - during the decomposition of all three compounds, and the temperatures at which SO 4 2 - is produced are different from each other. In the hybrid compound SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH, sulfate grafting between LDH layers first appears at 270 °C and is exclusively present above 400 °C. In situ HT-XRD was used to analyze the structural changes in SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH from 20 to 700 °C. The (0 0 6) peak of the SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH phase shifts relative to the (0 0 3) peak of the CO 3 2 - /LDH phase at 100 °C, due to the destruction of the hydrogen bonding area brought about by the removal of interlayer water. Both the (0 0 3) and (0 0 6) peaks of the CO 3 2 - /LDH phase disappear at 230 °C, indicating complete decarbonation which has been confirmed by in situ FT-IR spectroscopy at 250 °C. There are two observed decreases in d 0 0 3 basal spacing of SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH in the temperature range 20–150 °C and 200–350 °C. The first corresponds to the destruction of the interlayer hydrogen bonding area and the second is attributed to the decomposition of SO 3 -β-CD(6) anion and dehydroxylation of the LDH layers. The SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH phase disappears at 400 °C, which is in accordance with the analysis of the in situ FT-IR spectra where it is seen that SO 3 -β-CD(6) is converted to grafted SO 4 2 - at the same temperature. TPDE combined with GC-MS was used to study the decomposition process of the SO 3 -β-CD(6)/LDH. There are three strong peaks corresponding to the loss of adsorbed water, crystal water and decomposition of guest species, followed by further decomposition of guest species and finally the dehydroxylation of the host layers. The results are in accordance with those of TG-DTA analysis, except that the combustion of guest species observed in the TG-DTA was not observed in TPDE because of the inert atmosphere system employed in the latter. Despite the great versatility of modified cyclodextrins for chiral analyis using GC [13,40] , only a few are currently available as immobilized derivatives, the most common being Chirasil-β-Dex in which a permethylated β-cyclodextrin is immobilized on a polysiloxane support [40] . Immobilization is desirable in order to combine chemical selectivity with chromatographic efficiency, and increase the thermal stability thus extending the temperature range of operation. Our results show that combining sulfated cyclodextrins with the cationic layers of LDHs represents a potential route to a new type of stationary phase for chiral analysis. gfmCbFad.title: Structure and properties of layered manganese–vanadium oxide as a cathode material for lithium secondary batteries
gfmCbFad.abstract: Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O containing double sheets of V 2 O 5 layers has been synthesized by a new method – oxidation of VOSO 4 with layered MnO 2 . The Mn/V molar ratio is 0.068, and XPS indicates that the oxidation state of vanadium is +5 and that of manganese is +4. Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O has relatively promising lithium insertion properties, with a specific capacity of 200 mA h g −1 between 2.0 and 4.0 V, with the discharge capacity at the 18th cycle remaining as high as 208.3 mA h g −1 . Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O is therefore a potential practical candidate as the cathode material for rechargeable lithium batteries. Keywords Manganese vanadium oxide Oxidation Cathode material Lithium secondary battery Electrochemical behavior 1 Introduction There is much interest in manganese and vanadium oxides for use as cathode materials for advanced lithium batteries to replace the expensive and relatively low capacity lithium cobalt oxide system [1] . The use of so called 4-V cathodes which have voltage plateaus near 4 V demands a high electrochemical stability of the electrolyte. For liquid electrolytes, even the best candidate is not very stable at elevated temperatures and this leads to a gradual capacity loss when LiMn 2 O 4 is used as the 4-V cathode [2] . Cathodes such as LiMnO 2 , V 2 O 5 , and V 6 O 13 have voltage plateaus near 3 V and are called 3-V cathodes [2] . Despite their low voltage, 3-V cathodes usually have larger charge capacities, and therefore their energy storage densities are comparable to 4-V cathodes. Reversible lithium intercalation in vanadium pentoxide was first studied by Whittingham [3] , and vanadium-oxide-based materials have been studied extensively for use as cathodes in recent years. Many vanadium-oxide compounds are easy to synthesize, have acceptable production costs, and have good lithium capacity. The primary disadvantage is their poor cycle life [4] . A variety of synthetic methods have been used for vanadium oxide preparation including the gel method and various modifications there-of [5–10] , method based on ozone oxidation [11] , electrophoretic deposition [12] , r.f. sputtering [13] , film sputtering by physical vaporization [14] , and hydrothermal methods [15–17] . In recent years, considerable attention has been paid to a comparison of the properties of amorphous and crystalline samples of vanadium oxide [18–20] , as well as to the identification of phase transitions during the Li intercalation/deintercalation process [21–23] . Wiesener et al. [23] have demonstrated that the Li-ion chemical diffusion coefficient D is higher for an amorphous vanadium oxide cathode than for a crystalline one, resulting in a variation in lithium insertion capacity when used in lithium batteries. It has been shown that a V 2 O 5 xerogel [24] has a high capacity of about 340 mA h g −1 , while the capacity of a crystalline form is only about 150 mA h g −1 [16,17] . Several studies have demonstrated that the introduction of manganese ions between vanadium oxide layers can increase the number of possible lithium intercalation–deintercalation cycles. For example, reaction of KMnO 4 with VOSO 4 affords K 0.16 Mn 0. 04 V 2 O 4.94 · 0.14H 2 O [25] while reaction of N(CH 3 ) 4 MnO 4 with V 2 O 5 gives [17] materials of the type δ-[N(CH 3 ) 4 ] z Mn y V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O, both of which contain two types of interlayer cations. We were interested to prepare related material where manganese is the only interlayer cation and in this paper we report a simple synthesis of Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O by oxidation of VOSO 4 with layered δ-MnO 2 . The structure of the product has been characterized by X-ray diffraction (XRD), FT-IR spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and its performance as a cathode material in lithium secondary batteries has been examined. 2 Experimental δ-MnO 2 was obtained by thermal decomposition of KMnO 4 , followed by extraction of interlayer K + ions by acid treatment [26] . δ-MnO 2 (3.0 g, 0.034 mol) was added to a solution of VOSO 4 (9.8 g, 0.06 mol) in water (200 mL), and the reaction was accelerated by addition of sulfuric acid (93%, 1.5 mL). The mixture was stirred for 4 days at room temperature and then filtered. The resulting dark brown solid was washed well with water. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded using a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer in the range 3⩽2 θ ⩽70° using a monochromatized Cu Kα radiation source ( λ =1.5406 Å). Elemental analysis was performed by inductively coupled plasma emission (ICP) spectroscopy using a Shimadzu ICPS-7500 instrument. It gave the composition of the product by weight as follows: V 46.02% and Mn 3.41%. On TGA, this material lost 12.44% of its weight by 400 °C, which suggesting about 1.53 mol H 2 O per mol of Mn x V 2 O 5 . Sample morphology was investigated using a Hitachi H-800 transmission electron microscope. FT-IR spectra were recorded using the KBr pellet technique with a Bruker Vector-22 spectrometer. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were collected using a Thermo VG Sigma Probe X-ray photoelectron spectrometer with a Mg Kα X-ray source (200 W). In order to evaluate the electrochemical performance of the material, composite electrodes were formed by mixing the active material with acetylene black and polytetrafluoroethylene in the weight ratio 88.5/5/7.5, and then pressing into pellets. The composite electrodes were dried at 120 °C in vacuum for 24 h before use. Button-type cells were assembled in a dry box. A cell was prepared by assembling the cathode, separator, and the anode in a sandwich structure. The anode was lithium metal and the electrolyte was a 1 M solution of LiClO 4 in a mixture of ethylene carbonate (EC)/diethyl carbonate (DEC) in the volume ratio 1/1. The galvanostatic charge–discharge cycle was performed using a PCBT-64 cycle life tester and the cyclic voltammogram obtained at a scan rate of 0.1 mV/s using a Zahner IM6 electrochemical workstation. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and composition of the layered manganese–vanadium oxide The powder XRD patterns of δ-MnO 2 and the product obtained by reaction with VOSO 4 are shown in Fig. 1 . The reflections of δ-MnO 2 ( Fig. 1(a) ) can be indexed on a simple three-block cell commonly used for the description of layered manganese oxides. The XRD pattern of the product is similar to those of σ-Zn 0.25 V 2 O 5 [15] and M x V 2 O 5 A y · n H 2 O [4] . A single crystal study of the former has shown that the structure is a double sheet type composed of two V 2 O 5 sheets facing each other. We therefore propose that the product of the reaction of δ-MnO 2 with VOSO 4 is Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O with an analogous structure. The interlayer spacing is 1.07 nm, the same as that observed for σ-Zn 0.25 V 2 O 5 [15] . Elemental analysis of the product is consistent with the stoichiometry Mn 0.14 V 2 O 5.27 · 1.53H 2 O. Transmission electron micrographs ( Fig. 2 ) show that the manganese vanadium oxide was precipitated as a poorly crystalline material with an irregular plate-like appearance. The particle thickness is about 100–200 nm, which is consistent with the weak, broad basal diffraction peaks in the XRD pattern. Using the Scherrer equation, the average thickness of the platelets was estimated to be 12 nm. The FT-IR spectra for δ-MnO 2 and the product Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O are shown in Fig. 3 . Broad absorption peaks in the region 3200–3700 cm −1 can be assigned to O–H group stretching vibrations of the interlayer water molecules. A peak due to Mn–O vibrations was observed at 920 cm −1 in both the spectra of δ-MnO 2 and Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O, conforming the presence of Mn–O moieties in the product. As shown in Fig. 3(b) , additional peaks were found at 1008, 764 and 510 cm −1 in the spectrum of Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O. The band at 1008 cm −1 is due to the VO stretching vibration [16] , and bands at 764 and 510 cm −1 are associated with the vanadium oxide network [16,17] . X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy can provide chemical information about the oxidation state of elements present, as well as the semi-quantitative composition of the surface, and is thus a very useful method of studying surface conditions. Fig. 4 shows the XPS profiles of Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O in the manganese (635–660 eV) and vanadium–oxygen regions (510–545 eV). The binding energy of Mn 2p 3/2 is 642.0 eV, which indicates that the predominant Mn species present is Mn 4+ [27] . Compared with other signals, V 2p 3/2 is more sensitive to changes in oxidation state. The binding energy of V 2p 3/2 is at 517.9 eV, very close to that for V 5+ in V 2 O 5 . The O 1s peak at 530.8 eV also corresponds closely to that reported for V 2 O 5 [28] . Moreover, the O 1s peak shows a tail towards higher binding energy, similar to that observed for MnO 2 [29] , possibly resulting from interaction of Mn 4+ with H 2 O [28] . Oxidation states of Mn 4+ and V 5+ are both consistent with the analytical formula Mn 0.14 V 2 O 5.27 · 1.53H 2 O determined by elemental analysis (see above). XPS measurements using a semi-quantitative method [29] show that the molar ratio of Mn/V/O near the surface was 0.122/2.00/7.75. It can be seen that there is some surface contamination by oxygen, which may be related to the atmospheric present environment during measurement. The molar ratio Mn/V=0.061, is very close to the result obtained by ICP (Mn/V=0.068). This indicates that the composition near the surface is almost the same as that in the bulk. The low content of manganese in the sample indicates that most of the MnO 2 oxidant was reduced to soluble Mn 2+ species during the preparation of Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O and was removed by washing. The remaining manganese(IV) is possibly situated in the vanadium oxide bronze layers on the basis of its +4 oxygen state and the Mn–O absorption peak in its IR spectrum. 3.2 Electrochemical performance of Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O Selected charging and discharging curves over the first 15 cycles with Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O as cathode material in a lithium secondary battery are shown in Fig. 5 . The compound has an initial electromotive force (EMF) of 3.68 V, and 1.68 mol lithium per mol V 2 O 5 active material is incorporated into the structure on the first discharge. On recharge the capacity is 184.4 mA h g −1 , indicating that more than 90% of the lithium inserted into the structure can be removed below 4.0 V. As shown in Fig. 6 , the charge and discharge capacities remain essentially constant over 18 cycles, indicating the relatively stable and reversible electrochemical properties of this layered vanadium oxide. K 0.16 Mn 0.04 V 2 O 4.94 · 0.14H 2 O [25] obtained by hydrothermal reaction of KMnO 4 and VOSO 4 has a reversible capacity value of 190 mA h g −1 and a good capacity retention that is close to ours. TMA z Fe y V 2 O 5±δ · n H 2 O [16] crystalline has a good reversibility of the redox reaction in a lithium battery with a low capacity (0.88 mol Li per mol TMA z Fe y V 2 O 5±δ ). In our work, Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O has a higher reversible capacity and comparable cycling behavior to those reported in the literature. Fig. 7 shows the first four cyclic voltammograms obtained at a scan rate of 0.1 mV/s for the Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O electrode. Two pairs of well defined reduction and oxidation peaks are observed in the range 4.0–2.0 V, which is very similar to that reported by Shembel et al. [18] for ESVO. As shown in Fig. 7 , the voltammogram for Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O shows two reduction peaks at 2.90 and 2.25 V during the first scan, while in the second scan both peaks shift to higher potential (3.10 and 2.40 V, respectively). The voltammetric behavior of the layered Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O may indicate that the process of lithium insertion is accompanied by some phase rearrangement since changes in the position and profile of the peaks can be correlated with structural modifications in the layered host. In further cycles, two stable reduction and oxidation peaks appear, respectively, at 2.40/2.85 and 3.15/3.35 V, which indicates that two reversible redox reactions occur during charging and discharging processes. The peaks in the voltammogram for the lithium intercalation electrode are associated with different lithium occupation sites and the oxidation-reduction of vanadium ions. Furthermore, it should be noted that for the Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O material, primary lithium insertion does not induce an irreversible structure modification like that observed in V 2 O 5 [30] . For polycrystalline orthorhombic V 2 O 5 , the irreversible structural alterations are attributed to phase transition and/or phase segregation that reduces the specific capacity when the intercalation goes beyond x =1 in Li x V 2 O 5 [31] . However, this phenomenon has not been observed in the layered vanadium oxide Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O in this work. This suggests that Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O is a potential practical candidate as the cathode material for rechargeable lithium batteries. 4 Conclusions Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O was synthesized by a new method – oxidation of VOSO 4 with layered MnO 2 . Characterization by XRD indicates that the Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O has a layered structure, and can be indexed on the monoclinic system. Water molecules reside between double sheets of vanadium oxide. IR and XPS spectra indicate that Mn–O bonds exist in the sample and the oxidation state of the manganese is +4. Analysis by XPS and ICP shows very similar Mn/V molar ratios. The electrochemical behavior of Mn x V 2 O 5 · n H 2 O as a cathode material in lithium secondary batteries shows that this material exhibits high charge and discharge capacities of over 200 mA h g −1 between 2.0 and 4.0 V and excellent cycling stability with a discharge capacity of 208.3 mA h g −1 after 18 cycles. Cyclic voltammograms show that lithium intercalation/deintercalation processes are reversible. Acknowledgements This project was supported by the 863 Foundation of China (2001AA323020). mcgEjHll.title: Electrocatalytic oxidation of norepinephrine at a reduced C60-[dimethyl-(β-cyclodextrin)]2 and Nafion chemically modified electrode
mcgEjHll.abstract: The reduced C 60 -[dimethyl-(β-cyclodextrin)] 2 /Nafion chemically modified electrode is demonstrated to catalyze the electrochemical response of norepinephrine (NE) by cyclic voltammetry. A pair of well-defined redox waves were obtained and the calculated standard rate constant ( k s ) is 4.4×10 −3 cm s −1 at this reduced CME, indicating that the reduced C 60 -[dimethyl-(β-cyclodextrin)] 2 can act as promoter to the electron transfer of NE.

Xs49xC20.title: Studies on the intercalation of naproxen into layered double hydroxide and its thermal decomposition by in situ FT-IR and in situ HT-XRD
Xs49xC20.abstract: Layered double hydroxides, novel anionic clay, meet the first requirement as inorganic matrices for encapsulating functional drugs or biomolecules with negative charge in aqueous media. In this study, naproxen has been intercalated into Mg–Al layered double hydroxide by the methods of ion exchange. The structure and composition of the intercalated material have been studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD), UV–vis spectroscopy and inductively coupled plasma emission spectroscopy. A schematic model has been proposed. Furthermore, in situ Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, in situ high-temperature XRD, and thermogravimetry (TG) have been used to characterize the thermal decomposition of the hybrid material. It has been found that the thermal stability of the intercalated naproxen is significantly enhanced compared with the pure form before intercalation, which suggests that this drug-inorganic layered material may have prospective application as the basis of a novel drug delivery system.

VblVBym4.title: Bromide ion removal from contaminated water by calcined and uncalcined MgAl-CO3 layered double hydroxides.
VblVBym4.abstract: A fundamental investigation on the uptake of bromide ion from contaminated water by calcined and uncalcined MgAl-CO3 layered double hydroxides (LDHs) were conducted in batch mode. The uptake capacity of calcined LDHs (CLDH) is higher than that of uncalcined LDHs, due to their different mechanisms which are confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction, FT-IR spectroscopy and TG-MS measurements. The former mechanism is based on the reconstruction of CLDH to Br-LDHs, whilst the latter is related to the surface adsorption. It has been found that the LDHs calcined at 500 degrees C with Mg/Al molar ratio of 4 represents the highest capacity to remove bromide ion from aqueous solution. The equilibrium isotherms of uptake of bromide by CLDH were well fitted by the Langmuir equation, and thermodynamic parameters such as Delta G0, Delta H0 and Delta S0 were calculated from Langmuir constants. The negative value of Delta H0 confirms the exothermic nature of adsorption. Three kinetics models were used to fit the kinetics experimental data, and it was found that the pseudo-second order kinetics model could be used to describe the uptake process appropriately. The value of Ea was calculated to be 79.9 kJ/mol, which suggests that the process of uptake bromide is controlled by the reaction rate of bromide with the CLDH rather than diffusion.

rEiO5F0a.title: Structure and thermal decomposition of sulfated β-cyclodextrin intercalated in a layered double hydroxide
rEiO5F0a.abstract: The sodium salt of hexasulfated β -cyclodextrin has been synthesized and intercalated into a magnesium–aluminum layered double hydroxide by ion exchange. The structure, composition and thermal decomposition behavior of the intercalated material have been studied by variable temperature X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), inductively coupled plasma emission spectroscopy (ICP), and thermal analysis (TG-DTA) and a model for the structure has been proposed. The thermal stability of the intercalated sulfated β -cyclodextrin is significantly enhanced compared with the pure form before intercalation.

NTZYmVMA.title: Factors influencing the removal of fluoride from aqueous solution by calcined Mg-Al-CO3 layered double hydroxides.
NTZYmVMA.abstract: Layered double hydroxides (LDH) calcined at different temperatures (denoted as CLDH) have been demonstrated to recover their original layered structure in the presence of appropriate anions. In the light of this so-called "memory effect", a study of removal of fluoride from aqueous solution by calcined Mg-Al-CO(3)-LDH has been carried out. The LDH calcined at 500 degrees C had the highest capacity of removal of fluoride ion, because of retention of its intrinsic structure. The CLDH with an Mg/Al ratio of 2 has a remarkable ability to adsorb anions. The adsorption loading is higher for the calcined Mg-Al-LDH than for calcined Zn-Al and Ni-Al-LDH. The influence of varying the conditions for removal of fluoride, such as the pH of aqueous solution, the initial fluoride concentration, the dosage of adsorbent, and temperature on removal of fluoride have been investigated. The influence of co-existing anions in fluoride aqueous solution indicates that the percentage of removal of fluoride increased in order PO(4)(3-) < Cl(-) approximately SO(4)(2-) < Br(-) < NO(3)(-). It was found that maximum removal of fluoride from aqueous solutions was obtained in 6h at pH 6.0 with an initial concentration of 50 mg/L, and that the retention of fluoride ions by the CLDH material was 98% or higher. The residual fluoride concentration was found to be 0.4 mg/L with an initial concentration of 20 mg/L, which meets the national standard for drinking water quality. The Freundlich isotherm and Langmuir isotherm were used to fit the data of equilibrium experiments. The results of X-ray diffraction, FT-IR and TG-MS demonstrate that the adsorption phenomenon is accompanied by rehydration with concomitant uptake of fluoride ions to rebuild the initial layered structure.

nMYD6dZt.title: Photoelectric conversion properties of nanocrystalline TiO2 electrodes sensitized with hemicyanine derivatives
nMYD6dZt.abstract: Four hemicyanine derivatives, (E)-N-(3-sulfopropyl-4-[2-(4-dimethylaminophenyl)ethenyl]pyridinium (PS), (E)-N-(3-sulfopropyl-4-[2-(4-dimethylaminophenyl)ethenyl]quinolinium(QS), (E)-N-(3-sulfopropyl-4-[2-(4-N-methyl-N-hexadecylaminophenyl)ethenyl]pyridinium (LPS), and (E)-N-(3-sulfopropyl-4-[2-(4-N-methyl-N-hexadecylaminophenyl)ethenyl]quinolinium (LQS), have been synthesized and characterized with regard to their absorption and electrochemical properties. Photoelectrochemical experiments show that these hemicyanine dyes with D-π-A systems can yield efficient charge separation under illumination of simulated solar light. Alkyl chain has a remarkable effect on dye adsorbance, incident photon-to-electron conversion efficiency, and overall energy conversion yield. The overall yield is approximately doubled when the methyl group replaces the long alkyl chain. Action spectrum of QS displayed a broad feature with 33.8% of maximum monochromatic incident photon-to-electron conversion efficiency (IPCE), and a thin-layer sandwich-type solar cell based on nanocrystalline TiO2 film modified with QS produced about 2% of overall yield. For the first time, a photovoltaic liquid-junction solar cell based on nanostructured TiO2 electrode sensitized by hemicyanine dyes is reported. © 2000 American Chemical Society.

8Ie0a2Fi.title: Study of electrochemical properties of pyrrolidinofullerenes by microelectrode voltammetry
8Ie0a2Fi.abstract: The electrochemical behavior of nine pyrrolidinofullerenes has been investigated by cyclic voltammetry on a gold microdisk electrode. Four reversible reduction peaks and two irreversible reduction peaks are observed for each fullerene derivative. The half-wave potentials of all pyrrolidinofullerenes are more negative than those of C 60 itself. The diffusion coefficient of these compounds is measured by their steady-state voltammograms.

kVvtRNLE.title: Electrocatalysis of chloroacetic acids (mono-, di- and tri-) at a C60-[dimethyl-(β-cyclodextrin)]2 and nafion chemically modified electrode
kVvtRNLE.abstract: The C(60)-[dimethyl-(beta-cyclodextrin)](2) and nafion chemically modified electrode (CME) exhibits one electroreduction peak and two electro-oxidation peaks in a mixed solvent of water and acetonitrile (3:2, v/v) containing tetra-butylammonium perchlorate. The reduction of chloroacetic acids (mono-, di- and tri-) can be electrocatalyzed at this electrode, indicating that C(60)-[dimethyl-(beta-cyclodextrin)](2) is capable of mediating the electron transfer to chloroacetic acids. Values of the apparent catalytic rate constant, k, were determined by using the rotating-disk electrode (RDE).

126clacV.title: Electrochemical behavior of films of C60-dimethyl-(β-cyclodextrin) (1:1 and 1:2) inclusion complexes in mixed water and acetonitrile solutions
126clacV.abstract: Two inclusion complexes, i.e. C 60 -dimethyl-(β-cyclodextrin) and C 60 -[dimethyl-(β-cyclodextrin)] 2 , have been prepared by kneading and characterized by UV-vis and IR spectroscopy. Electrochemical behavior of their films has been studied by cyclic voltammetry (CV). The CVs are quite different from those for a pristine C 60 film. The CVs of films of both complexes are similar in a mixed solvent solution of water and acetonitrile (3:2, v/v) containing tetra- n -butylammonium perchlorate as supporting electrolyte. These CVs are characterized by one two-electron electroreduction peak and two one-electron electro-oxidation peaks when the rate is above 0.1 V s −1 . The one electroreduction peak of both films splits into two peaks if the potential scan rate is lower than 0.1 V s −1 .

TMjPYLyr.title: Comments on noncommutative gauge theories
TMjPYLyr.abstract: We study the gauge theories on noncommutative space. We employ the idea of the covariant position to understand the linear and angular momenta, the center of mass position, and to express all gauge invariant observables including the Wilson line. In addition, we utilize the universality of the U(1) gauge theory, which originates from the underlying matrix theory, to analyze various solitons on U(N) theories, like the unstable static vortex solutions in two dimensions and BPS dyonic fluxon solutions. © 2001 Published by Elsevier Science B.V.

lm8D4mnC.title: A structured catalyst based on cobalt phthalocyanine/calcined Mg-Al hydrotalcite film for the oxidation of mercaptan
lm8D4mnC.abstract: A structured catalyst has been fabricated by immobilizing cobalt phthalocyanine tetrasulfonate (CoPcS) on a mixed metal oxide (denoted as MMO) film, which exhibits excellent activity, stability and recyclability for mercaptan sweetening. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images show that the structured catalyst is composed of MMO nanoflakes whose ab-plane is perpendicular to the Al substrate, with desired mechanical strength and high adhesion to the substrate. In addition, in situ IR spectra and carbon dioxide temperature programmed desorption (CO2-TPD) reveal that the moderate basic site is overwhelming in the CoPcS/MMO structured catalyst, while the strong basic site predominates in the corresponding CoPcS/MMO powder catalyst. It was found that the structured catalyst exhibits high conversion (85.7%) for the oxidation of mercaptan to disulphide, markedly higher than that of the corresponding powder catalyst (38.7%), as a result of the high exposure of active species as well as the synergistic effect between the oxidation center (CoPcS) and the moderate basic site. In addition, the structured catalyst shows superior catalysis-regeneration performance, which facilitates its repeatable and cyclic usage over a long period. Therefore, this work provides a facile and effective method for the fabrication of structured catalyst with high catalytic activity and stability, as well as recyclability, which can be used as an eco-friendly catalyst for the sweetening process in the petroleum refining industry. © The Royal Society of Chemistry 2012.

HuHuddkN.title: Fabrication of hierarchical layered double hydroxide framework on aluminum foam as a structured adsorbent for water treatment
HuHuddkN.abstract: A hierarchical Mg-Al layered double hydroxide (LDH) framework has been fabricated via the in situ crystallization technique on aluminum foam, which can be used to remove heavy metal ion Cr(VI) and anionic dye (Remazol Brilliant Blue R, denoted as RBBR) from aqueous solutions. The as-prepared LDH/Al-foam displays flowerlike LDH microspheres composed of numerous LDH nanoplatelets, which was confirmed by XRD and SEM. The sorption kinetics of hierarchical LDH framework for Cr(VI) was appropriately described by a pseudo-second-order model. Sorption isotherms of both Cr(VI) and RBBR were also studied, which can be fitted by the Langmuir model more satisfactorily than the Freundlich one. It was found that the sorption capacities (q MAX) of the LDH framework reached 27.8 mg g -1 for Cr(VI) and 212.8 mg g -1 for RBBR, respectively, much larger than those of the corresponding LDH powder sample (21 mg g -1 for Cr(VI) and 166.7 mg g -1 for RBBR). Furthermore, the hierarchical LDH framework exhibits excellent sorption-regeneration performances compared with the powder sample, which facilitates its repeatable and cyclic usage over a long period. Owing to the high sorption capacity, low-cost preparation, convenient manipulation, and easy regeneration of the hierarchical LDH framework, it can be potentially used as a structured adsorbent in the field of water treatment. © 2011 American Chemical Society.

EeLmQN3Y.title: Immobilized Cu-Cr layered double hydroxide films with visible-light responsive photocatalysis for organic pollutants
EeLmQN3Y.abstract: Oriented Cu-Cr layered double hydroxide (LDH) films have been fabricated by the electrophoretic deposition method (EPD) on copper substrates, which can be used as photocatalysts for the degradation of organic pollutants under visible-light irradiation. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), scanning electron microscope (SEM), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) and Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) reveal that the resulting CuCr-LDH film possesses high crystallinity, porous structure as well as large specific surface area. UV-vis diffuse reflection spectroscopy (DRS) confirms that the CuCr-LDH film shows a broad absorption in visible light region (>400. nm). The LDH film thickness can be controlled precisely by adjusting voltage or time of EPD. The film with thickness of 16.5 μm shows excellent photocatalytic activity for the degradation of 2,4,6-trichlorophenol (2,4,6-TCP), sulforhodamine B (SRB) and Congo red. The photocatalytic reaction kinetics of 2,4,6-TCP was appropriately described by the pseudo-first-order model. In addition, the LDH film exhibits excellent recycleability compared with the corresponding powder sample, which facilitates its repeatable and cyclic usage over a long period. Owing to the high efficiency, low-cost preparation, easy manipulation and recyclability, it is expected that this film can be potentially used as photocatalyst in the field of water treatment. © 2012 Elsevier B.V.

V1wcwnZs.title: Synthesis and controlled release properties of prednisone intercalated mg-al layered double hydroxide composite
V1wcwnZs.abstract: A drug-inorganic composite involving prednisone-cholate ion micelles intercalated Mg-Al layered double hydroxide (LDH) has been assembled by a coprecipitation method. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD), Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR), and Uv-vis absorption spectroscopy indicate a successful intercalation of prednisone-containing micelles into galleries of the LDH matrix. The in vitro drug release studies show that no burst release phenomenon was observed at the beginning of release tests, and the pH value imposes very little influence on the release performance of prednisone in the studied pH range 4.8-7.6. It is, therefore, concluded that the MgAl-LDH can be used as an excellent inorganic drug carrier for prednisone in a wide range of pH values. Four kinetic models (first-order equation, Higuchi equation, Bhaskas equation, and Ritger-Peppas equation) were chosen to study the release kinetics of prednisone from the LDH carrier, and it was found that this process can be described by the Ritger-Peppas equation satisfactorily based on a directing Excel-based solver (DEBS). Moreover, the mechanism for drug release was also discussed. ©2009 American Chemical Society.

Xi09mMb1.title: Layer-by-layer assembly of layered double hydroxide/cobalt phthalocyanine ultrathin film and its application for sensors
Xi09mMb1.abstract: This paper reports the preparation of cobalt phthalocyanine/layered double hydroxide ultrathin films (UTFs) through an electrostatic layer-by-layer (LBL) technique as well as its application in electrocatalysis for dopamine oxidation. UV-vis absorption and electrochemical impedance spectra indicate the uniform deposition of the LBL films. XRD measurements demonstrate the long-range ordered structure of organic/inorganic UTFs, with an average repeating distance of 1.89 nm. SEM images show that the film surface displays a continuous and uniform morphology, with the root-mean-square (rms) roughness of ∼6.4 nm revealed by AFM. The UTF modified ITO electrode exhibits significant electrocatalytic performance for the oxidation of dopamine which is related to the Co(ii)/Co(iii) couple in the (LDH/CoPcTs) n UTF. The dopamine biosensor shows rather high sensitivity, low detection limit and excellent anti-interference properties in the presence of ascorbic acid. Furthermore, compared with pristine organic multilayer (PDDA/CoPcTs) n modified electrodes, the (LDH/CoPcTs) n electrodes show superior repeatability and long-term stability, due to the immobilization and dispersion of electroactive CoPcTs molecules by LDH nanosheets. Therefore, this work demonstrates a successful paradigm for the fabrication of electroactive species in an inorganic 2D matrix, which can be potentially used for practical applications in bioanalysis and biodetection. © The Royal Society of Chemistry.

JXCsZkbG.title: Biotemplated hierarchical nanostructure of layered double hydroxides with improved photocatalysis performance.
JXCsZkbG.abstract: We report a biomorphic hierarchical mixed metal oxide (MMO) framework through a biotemplated synthesis method. A uniform Al(2)O(3) coating was deposited on the surface of the biotemplate with an atomic layer deposition (ALD) process, and the film of ZnAl-layered double hydroxide (ZnAl-LDH), which faithfully inherits the surface structure of the biotemplate, was prepared by an in situ growth technique. Subsequently, a polycrystal ZnAl-MMO framework obtained by calcination of the LDH precursor has been demonstrated as an effective and recyclable photocatalyst for the decomposition of dyes in water, owing to its rather high specific surface area and hierarchical distribution of pore size. Therefore, the new strategy reported in this work can be used to fabricate a variety of biomorphic LDHs as well as MMO frameworks through replication of complicated and hierarchical biological structures for the purpose of catalysis, adsorbents, and other potential applications.

328yBYPC.title: Heterogeneous transparent ultrathin films with tunable-color luminescence based on the assembly of photoactive organic molecules and layered double hydroxides
328yBYPC.abstract: Multicolor luminescent films have great potential for use in optoelectronics, solid-state light-emitting materials, and optical devices. This work describes a systematic investigation of the ordered assembly of two- (blue/green, blue/orange, red/blue, red/green) and three-color (blue/red/green) light-emitting ultrathin films (UTFs) by using different photofunctional anions [bis(N-methylacridinium)@polyvinylsulfonate ion pairs and anionic derivatives of poly(p-phenylene), poly(phenylenevinylene), and poly(thiophene)] and Mg-Al-layered double hydroxide nanosheets as building blocks. The rational combination of luminescent components affords precise control of the emission wavelengths and intensity, and multicolored luminescent UTFs can be precisely tailored covering most of the visible spectral region. The assembly process of the UTFs and their luminescence properties, as monitored by UV-vis absorption and fluorescence spectroscopy, resulted in a gradual change in luminescence color in the selected light-emitting spectral region upon increasing the number of deposition cycles. X-ray diffraction demonstrates that the UTFs are periodic layered structures involving heterogeneous superlattices associated with individual photoactive anion-LDH units. These UTFs also exhibit well-defined multicolor polarized fluorescence with high polarization anisotropy, and the emissive color changes with polarization direction. Therefore, this work provides a way of fabricating heterogeneous UTFs with tunable-color luminescence as well as polarized multicolor emission, which have potential applications in the areas of light displays and optoelectronic devices. Heterogeneous two- (blue/green, blue/orange, red/blue, red/green) and three-color (blue/red/green) light-emitting ultrathin films have been fabricated using different photofunctional molecules and Mg-Al-layered double hydroxide nanosheets as building blocks. eB6LjXrl.abstract: A novel inorganic-organic composite ultrathin film was fabricated by layer-by-layer assembly of naphthol green B (NGB) and layered double hydroxides (LDHs) nanoplatelets, which shows remarkable electrocatalytic behavior for oxidation of ascorbic acid. LDHs nanoplatelets were prepared using a method involving separate nucleation and aging steps (particle size: 25±5 nm; aspect ratio: 2-4) and used as building blocks for alternate deposition with NGB on indium tin oxide (ITO) substrates. UV-vis absorption spectroscopy and XRD display regular and uniform growth of the NGB/LDHs ultrathin film with extremely c-orientation of LDHs nanoplatelets (ab plane of microcrystals parallel to substrates). A continuous and uniform surface morphology was observed by SEM and AFM image. The film modified electrode displays a couple of well-defined reversible redox peaks attributed to Fe(2+)/Fe(3+) in NGB (ΔE(p)=68 mV and I(a)/I(c)=1.1). Moreover, the modified electrode shows a high electrocatalytic activity towards ascorbic acid in the range 1.2-55.2 μM with a detection limit of 0.51 μM (S/N=3). The Michaelis-Menten constant was calculated to be K(M)(app)=67.5 μM.

WHCPdAqp.title: Anionic poly(p-phenylenevinylene)/layered double hydroxide ordered ultrathin films with multiple quantum well structure: a combined experimental and theoretical study.
WHCPdAqp.abstract: The sulfonated phenylenevinylene polyanion derivate (APPV) and exfoliated Mg-Al-layered double hydroxide (LDH) monolayers were alternatively assembled into ordered ultrathin films (UTFs) employing a layer-by-layer method, which shows uniform yellow luminescence. UV-vis absorption and fluorescence spectroscopy present a stepwise and regular growth of the UTFs upon increasing deposited cycles. X-ray diffraction, atomic force microscopy, and scanning electron microscopy demonstrate that the UTFs are orderly periodical layered structure with a thickness of 3.3-3.5 nm per bilayer. The APPV/LDH UTFs exhibit well-defined polarized photoemission characteristic with the maximum luminescence anisotropy of approximately 0.3. Moreover, the UTF exhibit longer fluorescence lifetime (3-3.85-fold) and higher photostability than the drop-casting APPV film under UV irradiation, suggesting that the existence of a LDH monolayer enhances the optical performance of the APPV polyanion. A combination study of electrochemistry and periodic density functional theory was used to investigate the electronic structure of the APPV/LDH system, illustrating that the APPV/LDH UTF is a kind of organic-inorganic hybrid multiple quantum well (MQW) structure with a low band energy of 1.7-1.8 eV, where the valence electrons of APPV can be confined into the energy wells formed by the LDH monolayers effectively. Therefore, this work not only gives a feasible method for fabricating a luminescence ultrathin film but also provides a detailed understanding of the geometric and electronic structures of photoactive polyanions confined between the LDH monolayers.

jTCwYQ4h.title: CdTe quantum dots/layered double hydroxide ultrathin films with multicolor light emission via layer-by-layer assembly
jTCwYQ4h.abstract: Quantum dots (QDs) luminescent films have broad applications in optoelectronics, solid-state light-emitting diodes (LEDs), and optical devices. This work reports the fabrication of multicolor-light-emitting ultrathin films (UTFs) with 2D architecture based on CdTe QDs and MgAl layered double hydroxide (LDH) nanosheets via the layer-by-layer deposition technique. The hybrid UTFs possess periodic layered structure, which is verified by X-ray diffraction. Tunable light emission in the red-green region is obtained by changing the particle size of QDs (CdTe-535 QDs and CdTe-635 QDs with green and red emision respectively), assembly cycle number, and sequence. Moreover, energy transfer between CdTe-535 QDs and CdTe-635 QDs occurs based on the fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET), which greatly enhances the fluorescence efficiency of CdTe-635 QDs. In addition, a theoretical study based on the Förster theory and molecular dynamics (MD) simulations demonstrates that CdTe QDs/LDH UTFs exhibit superior capability of energy transfer owing to the ordered dispersion of QDs in the 2D LDH matrix, which agrees well with the experimental results. Therefore, this provides a facile approach for the design and fabrication of inorganic-inorganic luminescent UTFs with largely enhanced luminescence efficiency as well as stability, which can be potentially applied in multicolor optical and optoelectronic devices. © 2012 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim.

lhr95W4u.title: Organic-inorganic hybrid fluorescent ultrathin films and their sensor application for nitroaromatic explosives
lhr95W4u.abstract: The luminescent film materials sensitive to external stimuli are important to develop new types of optical sensors and switches. Herein we report organic-inorganic hybrid ultrathin films (UTFs) with reversible luminescence response to nitroaromatic explosive compounds by the use of layer-by-layer assembly of optical brightener BBU and Mg-Al-layered double hydroxide (LDH) nanosheets. UV-Visible absorption and fluorescence spectroscopy showed an orderly growth of the BBU/LDH films upon increasing the number of deposition cycle. XRD, AFM and SEM measurements indicated that the films feature periodic layered structure with a period of ca. 2 nm as well as uniform surface morphology. The BBU/LDH UTFs exhibit well-defined one/two-photon polarized photoemission with the anisotropy as high as 0.38. Moreover, the UTFs show a fast, selective and reversible luminescence response to different nitroaromatic explosives with the most significant luminescent red-shift occurring for picric acid; in addition, by combining suitable luminescent building blocks, the films can also be extended to other dual-color luminescence systems, which exhibit changes in both luminescence intensity and ratiometric fluorescence upon interaction with explosives, enlightening that these films can serve as new types of selective solid luminescent sensors towards nitroaromatic compounds. © The Royal Society of Chemistry 2013.

iVU0fGiv.title: Luminescent ultrathin film of anionic styrylbiphenyl derivative-layered double hydroxide and its reversible sensing for heavy metal ions.
iVU0fGiv.abstract: Ordered ultrathin films (UTFs) with blue luminescence based on a styrylbiphenyl derivative (BTBS) and Mg-Al-layered double hydroxide (LDH) nanosheets have been constructed employing the layer-by-layer assembly technique. UV-visible absorption and fluorescence spectroscopy showed a stepwise and regular growth of the films upon increasing the number of deposition cycles. XRD, AFM and SEM indicated that the films possess a periodic layered structure with a period of ca. 1.5 nm, and uniform surface morphology. The film thickness can be precisely controlled in the range ca. 15-53 nm. The BTBS-LDH UTFs exhibit improved UV-light resistance capability compared with the pristine BTBS and show well-defined polarized photoemission, with anisotropy of ca. 0.24. The UTFs show a fast, selective and reversible luminescent response to aqueous solutions containing different heavy metal ions, with the most significant luminescent quenching occurring for the Hg(2+) solution, shedding light on the fact that these films can serve as a new type of selective solid luminescent metal-ion sensor.

qESTW4pj.title: Layer-by-layer assembly of bi-protein/layered double hydroxide ultrathin film and its electrocatalytic behavior for catechol.
qESTW4pj.abstract: This paper reports the fabrication of a bi-protein/layered double hydroxide (LDH) ultrathin film in which hemoglobin (HB) and horseradish peroxidase (HRP) molecules were assembled alternately with LDH nanosheets via the layer-by-layer (LBL) deposition technique, and its electrocatalytic performances for oxidation of catechol were demonstrated. The results of XRD indicate that the HB-HRP/LDH ultrathin film possesses a long range stacking order in the normal direction of the substrate, with the two proteins accommodated in the LDH gallery respectively as monolayer arrangement. SEM images show that the film surface exhibits a continuous and uniform morphology, and AFM reveals the Root-Mean-Square (RMS) roughness of ∼10.2 nm for the film. A stable direct electrochemical redox behavior of the proteins was successfully obtained for the HB-HRP/LDH film modified electrode. In addition, it exhibits remarkable electrocatalytic activity towards oxidation of catechol, based on the synergistic effect of the two proteins. The catechol biosensor in this work displays a wide linear response range (6-170 μM, r=0.999), low detection limit (5 μM), high sensitivity and good reproducibility.
